repnme.cdata!: Pakistan - Rural communities push back poverty

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about rural
            communities pushing back poverty in Pakistan. Pakistan has a
            population of over 162 million, with over 60 percent living
            in rural areas. Rising food prices, the energy crisis, and
            other inflationary pressures have not only pushed more
            people below the poverty line, but have increased
            vulnerability of the ultra-poor to an unprecedented level.
            The rising levels of ethnic and religious strife, conflict
            and insecurity, and recurring natural calamities have
            further limited the country’s capacity to deal effectively
            with persistent poverty. The International Development
            Association financed Pakistan Poverty Alleviation Fund
            (PPAF) in 1999 to support government efforts to empower poor
            people to achieve sustainable livelihoods. The objective was
            to increase their incomes, improve their productive
            capacity, and provide them better access to services. The
            project facilitated the formation of inclusive community
            groups, with the aim of increasing economic activity, skills
            enhancement, asset base, infrastructure access, and market
            linkages. The third PPAF (PPAF III) project was launched in
            2009, built on successful PPAF experiences and further
            targeted marginalized groups of the most vulnerable and
            poorest households, including women. PPAF III promoted
            stronger community institutions, particularly their ability
            to manage their own development and to access services.
            Access to social and physical infrastructure were fully
            integrated to maximize the impact on poverty. Furthermore,
            there was a major effort to provide increased occupational
            skills training, with the goal of spurring exponential
            growth in micro-enterprises.

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows; Project
            outcome is satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is satisfactory.
            Key lessons learnt during the implementation of this project
            are also reflected in the design of the follow- on PPAF-II
            project. These include: 1) needing a holistic approach to
            improve access to services and reduce poverty which combines
            micro-credit with small scale infrastructure, education, and
            health facilities as well as skill development; 2) autonomy
            and freedom from political pressures; 3) the need for
            Institutional development of pro-poor institutions,
            including strategic reviews, SWOT (strength, weaknesses,
            opportunities and threats) analysis, mandatory submissions
            of business plans, targeted training, capacity building of
            staff, and strengthening of financial and monitoring
            functions; 4) the ability of decentralization to enable
            organizations to respond rapidly and successfully to
            community needs; 5) the hiring of staff by PPAF through a
            transparent and merit based procedures with policies of
            compensation and staff development clearly articulated and
            reviewed to keep staff motivated; and 6) making program
            interventions demand driven.  Other key lessons cited are:
            Government support is absolutely essential for the success
            of the apex institution. The level of donor support and
            facilitation, or the absence of it, can make or break the
            project. A competent and committed Board of Directors makes
            the task at hand much easier. A fully competent Chief
            Executive can achieve better and quicker results. Building
            of trust is the key to achieving sustainable development.
            Development is an on-going process which is continually evolving.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Pakistan Poverty Alleviation Fund
            (PPAF) Project seeks to alleviate poverty and empower the
            rural and urban poor, by providing them with access to
            resources and services. There are five project components.
            1) Micro-credit will provide loans to partner organizations
            (POs) for on-lending to individuals or groups of individuals
            who meet the eligibility criteria of the PPAF at rates that
            ultimately cover their directly attributable credit
            administrative costs, loan loss, cost of funds and
            reasonable profit to maintain real value of equity. 2)
            Community infrastructure will support, in the form of grants
            on a cost sharing basis, small scale community
            infrastructure sub-projects to improve the quality of life
            of the poor. 3) Capacity building of partner organizations
            will support, in the form of grants, capacity building of
            communities and POs to improve their effectiveness in
            implementing poverty alleviation programs. 4) Capacity
            building of the PPAF will support operating costs, staff
            training, technical assistance for various studies and cost
            of fixed assets. 5) Endowment from the Government of
            Pakistan will provide US$10 million to serve as PPAF's
            equity. Interest earned will support PPAF's core
            institutional costs.
